docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Ethics Committee today accused Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate's most important committee, of bringing "discredit upon the United States Senate" through sexual misconduct, tampering with evidence and seeking help from lobbyists to get his wife a job. After a 30-month investigation, which Senator Packwood delayed at one point by going to court in a futile effort to block a subpoena for his diaries, the committee said it had found "substantial credible evidence" for each of its three charges.

headline.main: Ethics Panel in Senate Accuses Packwood of Sexual Misconduct

docs.snippet: The Senate Ethics Committee today accused Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate's most important committee, of bringing "discredit upon the United States Senate" through sexual misconduct, tampering with evidence and seeking help from lobbyists to get...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who knows as much about welfare policy as anyone in the country, has broken a silence on the issue with a blast of scorn for nearly everyone engaged in the battle on Capitol Hill. He has ridiculed Republicans for proposing "punishing, punitive" welfare reform and President Clinton for inviting the G.O.P. attack by promising reforms he could not achieve. The Senator offers a welfare plan of his own that provides an alternative to root for. The criticism of Mr. Clinton is partly unfair. Yes, his campaign to impose time limits on welfare benefits invited the G.O.P. to press for even harsher limits. But at least he acknowledged the Government's responsibility to provide jobs -- along with child care and health insurance -- to recipients who exhaust their benefits but cannot find employment. The President can more properly be faulted for disappearing from the debate. He needs to back up his approach by pledging to veto any bill that strips poor families of all Federal guarantees of cash and food assistance. At least then, the Democrats will stand for something firm and just.

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the world came crashing down on Doris Sanders. Within a few hours, she received a notice of eviction from her home of 19 years and she learned she was dying of cancer. Mrs. Sanders, 48, is fighting back on both fronts. But if her course of therapy should fail, she has one final wish: to live out her remaining days in the home she and her husband, Robert E. Payne, bought in 1976.

headline.main: Dying of Cancer, Woman Battles Bank on Eviction

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress rolls toward a vote this week on more than $250 billion in Medicare savings, a variety of health policy experts say there is no magic formula for extracting that much money from the program by 2002, the Republicans' self-imposed deadline for balancing the Federal budget. Slowing spending that much in that short a time almost certainly would mean charging beneficiaries more while squeezing payments to hospitals and other health care providers, these experts say.

headline.main: MEDICARE TARGET COULD BE ELUSIVE, MANY EXPERTS SAY

docs.snippet: As Congress rolls toward a vote this week on more than $250 billion in Medicare savings, a variety of health policy experts say there is no magic formula for extracting that much money from the program by 2002, the Republicans' self-imposed deadline...

docs.lead_paragraph: Now we know how House Republicans hope to pay for the huge $350 billion tax cut they have promised -- with rosy projections of savings and revenues that may never materialize. If the forecasts go awry, the Republicans would be forced in future years to clamp down on spending even more harshly than they are now proposing. Both Representative John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, and Senator Pete Domenici, his Senate counterpart, have proposed cutting domestic discretionary spending by 30 percent to balance the budget by 2002. But Mr. Kasich needs to find far more savings than Mr. Domenici, whose plan does not include tax cuts that are heavily weighted toward upper-income families.

headline.main: A Budget Harsher Than It Seems

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, asked yesterday for a state law requiring insurance companies to reimburse new mothers for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. Speaking before a meeting of the New Jersey Assembly's Advisory Council on Women at Holy Name Hospital here, she said that some insurers, to cut costs, have proposed reducing coverage of a hospital stay after birth to as little as 12 hours. "We could just go back to the 'good old days' when women delivered babies in the field, turned right around and went back to harvesting the crops," Representative Roukema said. "That would save us money, but it would also give us third world standards."

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing; More Coverage for Mothers

docs.lead_paragraph: The quality of American health care -- unarguably the best in the world -- is under siege. Republicans released budget plans last week that would cut subsidies to teaching hospitals that train doctors and perform clinical research. Meanwhile, the private market, whose reform Congress bungled last year, has been doing the same. The two-pronged assault is alarming. American physicians provide innovative, technically advanced care whose quality can be traced in part to generous subsidies for basic research that Congress has provided through the National Institutes for Health. The N.I.H. estimates that the Senate budget plan could reduce these subsidies for non-AIDS research over the next seven years by as much as 25 percent; the cut is deeper if inflation is taken into account.
